title: What will OPEC+ decide to do with regard to oil production at its next meeting?
possible_answers: The next OPEC+ will not be held before 1 February 2021
preds: @SE_Meyer @Econja2018  I expect you have seen this info - https://youtu.be/glyfMIVCRXA & https://bloom.bg/2XmdREU - that Saudi will make a voluntary cut of 1mb/d. As previously thought, concerns linger over US shale production being increased. Those concerns publicly voiced by Russia. Saudi now seems to be firmly back in control in OPEC - https://bloom.bg/3njlRRG. However, my reading of this https://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/Voluntary%20Production%20Levels.pdf and this, https://bit.ly/3s1DCbH is that with Saudi's cuts and the agreed outputs, production is being reduced from 7.2 mb/d that was agreed for Jan 2021 to 7.125 mb/d for Feb and 7.05 mb/d for March. What are your views?

@SE_Meyer  Based on this, https://bit.ly/3hOVL8a this, https://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/Voluntary%20Production%20Levels.pdf  and this, https://reut.rs/2KY8J7A - it appears the consensus is to allow Russia & Kazakhstan to increase production while OPEC members absorb the increase for February and March.
Corona vaccine coming up, question is whether or not it will have an imminent impact or require longer time.
that'll teach me about being too reactive
I read this as an increase, based on the official quotas. https://oilprice.com/Energy/Oil-Prices/OPEC-Meeting-Ends-With-Major-Surprise-Cut-From-Saudi-Arabia.html
Todays update from OPEC - Rus agreed to roll over and stick with production levels for Feb.

With Crude prices on the rise again (insider info leaks assumed), this is almost completely open.
Await a decision not today, but tomorrow - or no agreement at all.

I think the role of Kazakhstan (non-OPEC, supporting Russia's stance) and Iraq (OPEC, over-production after the past meeting likely) is underestimated.
This could again end up in a OPEC/non-OPEC volume/market share/price war. There is good reason for non-OPECs to insist on and make their case for higher volume, if Iraq's production actually outnumbered its quota. Discipline applies to all in the game collectively, and if one deserts, Saudi Arabia and the other OPEC will have to offer something to maintain the rule of OPEC+.
https://seekingalpha.com/news/3648631-how-much-oil-can-market-take-clash-opec
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OPEC#OPEC+_members
With monthly meetings the urgency to raise is lower. Saudis are on convincing mode and lower oil price today makes it easier

Talks adjourned until the 5th, on the basis that the Saudis could still win the argument, but allow Russia to save face by allowing a small increase, I am leaving that as the favoured outcome, but without much conviction (56/44).
With Saudi Arabia opposed and digging their heels in, I think there is unlikely to be an increase.

Jan 4th
Today’s meeting adjourned without consensus being met. Opening comments from S.A. oil minister urged prudence and restraint (see below) and sources report that most countries now favour continuing current output ceilings.
Russia and Kazakhstan still want to increase by 500k bpd, however, UAE have changed their stance, and now support a rollover.
Iraq, Nigeria also support rollover. Opening remarks by chairman of OPEC - S.A Minister of Energy:
https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/press_room/6305.htm
@SE_Meyer  Indecision rules after today's session and wrangling is set to continue tomorrow - https://reut.rs/3rPGkRA

@SE_Meyer  Some  more info to add to the equation - https://reut.rs/38WB0mM and https://reut.rs/2X5XBYG - seems to indicate some acknowledgement of pressure to reduce the output reduction. Perhaps 125,000 bbl/day. But the concerns about demand seem to carry more weight. Not sure how you read this - https://bit.ly/3hFnOXi, but, the perception I have is this is a suggestion that an increase in supply would be better in H2 2021.

New news this morning:  Barkindo highlighting downside risks yesterday; oil price has increased significantly on market belief that output will be kept as is and will not be increased; OPEC sources have also said that most countries favour to hold any increases in Feb.
Given previous comments from S.A about 'keeping traders on their toes', this is still not totally clear cut, so tightening the spread.

@SE_Meyer See https://reut.rs/38WB0mM Concerns have been raised about the impact of the new strain of coronavirus on demand and hence the need to temper any increase in production to maintain pricing.

Supposed to meet today/ Monday. Looking KSA and the opec secretary are being a lot more cautious and highlighting downside risk In this round of negotiations I am expecting Russia and to lesser extent the emirates to follow the line. Their overtures to increase haven’t been met.  Steady as she goes seems to be the mantra.  Now of course this could be opening salvo in bunch of horse trading but I clear what concessions might be on the table. Also don’t see the point in keeping the market in suspense per se, outside of balancing price expectations  https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/business/opec-oil-outlook-first-half-2021-downside-risks-covid-19-13888216

Price momentum positive due to US stimulus package, positive vaccine news and non-OECD development - global inventories falling slightly and market has capacity for increase supply without this pulling the price down.
Russian stance clear (upward); UAE, Nigeria (big trade deficit) and Iraq seem to favour increase. S.A. unclear.
Upgrading probability of production being adjusted upward significantly to 70.

World economy not yet ready to assume an increase in oil prices. As soon as jobs, airlines, and other activities return to a certain normality then OPEC may think to adjust prices. On the other side if not adjustments, then no sense to held a meeting.

I am surprised by the strength of the consensus here given the only thing cited seems to be Russia’s public statements. However I have a bad track record in oil and market seems concerned, so revising towards the consensus (getting about half way there). https://www.worldoil.com/news/2020/12/28/oil-price-rally-fades-as-opec-s-plans-overshadow-us-stimulus

The next OPEC+ meeting is scheduled for tomorrow (January 4th, https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/press_room/6267.htm), so there's only an outside chance it's not held before the 1st of February. With oil prices continuing to increase after the upwards adjustment agreed December 3rd (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/topics/cmjpj223708t/oil), a downwards adjustment seems almost as unlikely. Between no adjustment and an upwards move, the fundamentals appear to favour the latter (budget deficits to narrow, investments to realise, market share to recover). Russia's openly pushing for such an increase and noone seems to be openly opposing the move (https://www.worldoil.com/news/2021/1/1/opecplus-2021-how-to-increase-oil-output-without-undoing-2020-s-gains). But since meetings'll now be monthly, members may wait until February.

The next OPEC + meeting ii Mon, Jan 4 by video conference - https://bit.ly/353fjjS Considering the 'success' of the 2020 Declaration of Cooperation (DoC) amongst OPEC + members it is likely members will be pushing for increased production limits in order to generate income. The balance between the member countries' income requirements and the global supply (including the US supply) and the coronavirus impact is a fine line. Demand for oil and oil products from non-OPEC + countries is at best stable over the last few months. Demand from aviation and cruising has slumped in 2021 and road transport demand is considerably lower. However, OPEC + member countries have also been widely affected by the pandemic and thus need 'additional' income to shore up their economies. US shale & Canadian sand production profitability is marginal at current prices. Thus OPEC + can probably afford to increase production to a) keep prices current, b) close out potentially increased US & Canadian production and c) generate additional revenues over the medium term now that coronavirus vaccines are being rolled out in developed countries. See https://bit.ly/3b3pxoa / https://bit.ly/3aWigqe / https://reut.rs/2KVkefR and https://bloom.bg/3oaEXdR @SE_Meyer
Consensus is lacking , therefore no point to meet.

Price is rising well, and has been throughout December. Although demand is forecasted to be slightly lower, there is also significant pressure from member nations to increase production (notably Nigeria who are operating a significant trade deficit due to lower oil production) and this is in light of recent further news re C19 vaccines (notable AstraZeneca on Dec 30th). A further increase from Feb is supported by Rus provided prices are stable and within a 45 - 55 USD range.  
Moreover, increasing production by <= 500k b/pd shouldn't pull prices down, but will be helpful to member nations and a step towards the 2m b/pd April target. Although Mohamed Abdalaziz Bin Salman (S.A Energy Minister) was quoted as saying he wanted to 'keep traders on their toes' this seems like bluster.

Updating as we are close to the meeting date.
No news indicating the meeting won't happen so downgrading to 1.
Oil price has continued to be stable and moving higher, and Russia still wants to adjust production upward, so downgrading downward production to 0. 
It also looks like I misinterpreted the media reports about the meeting, the official press release (https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/press_room/6257.htm) seems to suggest that the burden of proof lies with those countries that don't want a production increase, so moving upward production to 80 and the no change to 19.

https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/OPEC-Compliance-Continues-To-Exceed-100.amp.html With UAE too(traditional allies with Saudis who have seen their relationship grow cold recently) eyeing a more aggressive role in terms of ramping up production. Feel that the Saudis may have a hard time trying to stop an increase in production

Unless prices collapse, another 500,000 barrel increase seems to have already been agreed on. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-opec-russia/novak-says-russia-backs-opec-500000-bpd-oil-output-hike-from-february-idUSKBN28Z0AS

Reasons to increase production:
- Pressure/dissatisfaction from countries. Russia's PM said they will push for production increase.
Before December's meeting: "In the run-up to this week’s meeting, reports surfaced of discontent among smaller members – notably Iraq, Kazakhstan and the United Arab Emirates (UAE)." [1]
"Russia’s deputy prime minister said the nation plans to support a further gradual increase in OPEC+ production at the next meeting in January, because crude prices are within an optimal range." [4] - Historically, if OPEC reduced production, there was a risk that America and others would gain more market share by increasing production. So if OPEC felt like that was a risk, that would be a reason to increase production. However, American shale oil production is down, so don't see this as a risk.
"Not only did some members consistently produce more than they promised to, but producers outside the agreement, such as America, seized the opportunity to increase their own market shares." [2]
"At the same time, U.S. shale oil production continues to decline. The latest "Drilling Productivity Report" from the U.S. Energy Information Administration showed U.S. unconventional oil output averaged 7.70 million barrels per day in November and is expected to decline to 7.58 million b/d in December and 7.44 million b/d in January 2021." [5]
"In effect, what OPEC+ is trying to do is achieve a trifecta of increasing their volumes, keeping prices at least at current levels, and finally not surrendering market share to producers outside the group, such as the United States and Brazil." [3] Reasons to not adjust production:
- Predictions going into December's meeting were that production would not be adjusted, and then production was increased, so it would make sense to not adjust production in January.
Before December's meeting: "Alegria’s energy minister, who currently holds OPEC’s rotating presidency, reportedly said on Monday that the cartel reached a consensus to extend cuts by three months. That would reinforce the status quo on prices say, analysts, while a six-month extension would help clear the storage glut and lift prices meaningfully." [1]
"This week OPEC+ will debate a second such production increase. With new lockdowns further hurting demand, the coalition is expected to defer it. OPEC countries such as Nigeria and Iraq, struggling under the burdens of covid-19 and reduced oil revenue, are unhappy. But without a sustained increase in demand, the coalition has little choice but to put up with painful limits." [2] - Uncertainty in demand due to COVID, vaccine, lockdowns, and stimulus
"What this likely means is that more than OPEC+’s 500,000 bpd may be added to the global markets in January, at a time when it’s still too early for the multiple vaccines to have had any impact on boosting travel, or on opening borders." [3]
""We believe a material increase in oil demand is unlikely to happen before [the second quarter of 2021] when we expect vaccines to become widely available." To complicate matters, a new, faster-spreading virus has raised concerns that tighter restrictions will impact the oil demand recovery." [5] Reasons to decrease production: 
- I can't think of any because oil prices have been stable. No meeting before February 1:
- OPEC+ meeting is scheduled Jan 4. Even if for some reason it didn't happen on Jan 4, there would still be plenty of time to reschedule. Forecasts:

No adjustment: 59%
Adjust downward: 1%

https://www.worldoil.com/news/2020/12/25/russia-plans-to-back-another-opecplus-production-hike-in-february Russia is pushing for modest hike whilst KSA is silent. However they are the power brokers after this years price war.  A slight increaSe in face of stable oil prices is an easy route. No immediate need to cut

There is around 5 mb/d of spare capacity idle in OPEP, so there is a big incentive to put that production back into the market as soon as possible. At $50 + Brent prices OPEP it is a good price to sell as much as possible. On top of that apparent demand is going down , so that is an extra incentive to sell more oil at this prices before it goes down again.
Stable oil prices means Russia is keen to get revenue in

I guess it is too early after new year, nothing happens first month and also situation with vaccine is still not completely clear. However, it is stated 4th Jan on opec website. So probably it will happen.
Vaccine status is still "in progress", dont think everyone will be vaccinated till April 2021. So demand will not increase and hence production will still be cut.
Why not further decrease? I guess because oil price is stable.

Russia wants an increase in February. Iran is looking to increase strategic ties with Russia to shore up against potential sanctions from US. The OPEC meeting will occur before January 20th, making a 'wait and see' approach the most likely.
Crowd Wisdom until I do research
Will lean towards inaction and wait and see.

Given how difficult the last meeting was to agree, the next meetings proximity as well as the fact that the oil price has climbed roughly 6% since, there appears to be no reason to reduce production downwards (2%). Postponing the meeting by more than a month, seems to make little sense either as even difficult meetings get postponed by only a few days historically (2%)
There clearly is a chance they want to try and tweak the production upward by a small amount again given the price rise, and those that were arguing for a bigger increase in their last meeting will have had their hand strengthened, so will allocate 30% chance there (not higher as the last meeting was difficult). Which leaves 64% that they leave production unchanged.

Looks like Saudi Arabia wants to hold the production at current level while Russia & UAE want to increase the production [1]. Nobody will be able to make the case for decreasing the production as the prices are up over last 30 days. [1] https://www.investing.com/analysis/with-oil-prices-divorced-from-demand-realities-whats-opecs-next-best-move-200548225

Most likely production will be adjusted upward to please countries already reeling from the fiscal costs of COVID-19, commodity prices are slowly rising and OPEC will be confident they can raise production without dramatically affecting price
too early for bounceback demand increases

Given the increase at the December meeting and OPEC recent downgrade in their 2021 forecast, it is very likely that OPEC will hold steady at its Jan21 meeting. The second most likely choice would be a small increase in production. This will especially be likely if vaccine rollouts continue at a robust pace and the global economy begins to see an uptick in demand in early 21. However, these impacts would likely not been seen until at least late Feb or Mar. It is likely that ministers would cancel their meeting if it appears things have not begun to pick up or are detoriating. Given the December increase, OPEC will look for any option to not cut output again.

The demand would be sapped by the surge of covid cases. 
Further increase in oil price would stimulate shale production. 
other commodity prices falls.

Looking at the 2021 oil report from december 2020 and the 12th ONOMM press release from OPEC I Expect either a small increase, like in December, or no decision before januari 2021. I also allow for the possibility of no meeting January 2021.
I suspect a small increase or no decision based on the ONOMM press release stating the intention to "gradually return 2 mb/d, given consideration to market conditions."  The report points to monthly ministerial meetings at which production increase for the next month will be decided "being no more than 0.5 mb/d." Given the recent rally in oil prices, and the commitment to raise production gradually, I give a 10% point advantage to a production increase. 
I suspect a very small change of a decrease, if the economic forecast for 2021 take a turn for the worst.
There is also a small change of no meeting before februari 2021 even though the commitment was made during the 12th OPEC meeting.
These oil producing countries have showed a tendency to shoot themselves in the foot so the probability of no decision or increase production is high.

Futures oil prices indicate increased optimism for expanded global economic growth following approval of Covid-19 vaccines and the start of vaccinations in UK & US and expected in EU in the coming days. however, in reality, the bulk of the world's population is unlikely to see vaccination before Q3-Q4 2021. The spread of new Covid-19 cases in the northern hemisphere has lead to restrictions and stronger lockdowns that were in excistance a month ago. This will impact both land and air based transport and hence oil demand. Today's spot prices for Brent, WTI are roughly 5%-10% more than current spot. While that may not sound very positive, consider that futures were negative in April 2020, albeit only for a day. OPEC + in effect is a fairly fine balancing act in that both the OPEC and Declaration of Cooperation (DOC) members would all like to produce more to generate greater revenues. However, flooding the market in all likelihood would collapse the price. Against that background and the potential for US shale production to increase quite quickly should oil prices increase much more, and the reasonably large stocks China has both on and offshore, may have to retain the current cuts.
Notes from OPEC meeting in Dec 2020 (https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/press_room/6257.htm) indicate a commitment to gradually raise oil production ('paragraph' 7).

The OPEC Member That Could Derail The Production Cut Plan By Cyril Widdershoven - Dec 10, 2020, 5:00 PM CST
 "After a week of contentious OPEC+ discussions, in which the UAE played a key role, it appears that the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) is now aggressively pursuing market share. The UAE was very vocal during the OPEC+ meeting about its resentment of having to carry the burden of COVID-19 demand destruction and the global energy transition. Abu Dhabi’s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Zayed and ADNOC’s CEO Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber have now clearly decided that it is time to reap the rewards of their large-scale oil and gas investments." "In the coming months, the full intentions of Abu Dhabi will likely be revealed, but recent developments suggest that it is determined to move forward aggressively."

I believe OPEC will decide to delay their decision until at least Mar or Apr regarding increasing oil output. This will allow for increased future and current prices as COVID vaccine news propels economic recovery globally.
